EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
    Raytheon Vision Systems, located at 75 Coromar Drive, Goleta, CA, operates a gaseous chlorine disinfection system for non-potable groundwater used in manufacturing operations. 
a) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
    The cylinders are equipped with manual shutoff valves and Capital Control Advance Series 200 vacuum gas feeders. The cylinders supply chlorine gas via the vacuum feeders and 1/4 inch plastic tubing to an air stripper tower located inside the B4 well house. A MSA chlorine gas detection system and alarm are installed in the chlorine cylinder enclosure and wired directly to the Raytheon Command Center. Only one cylinder is active (manually opened) at any time, and a single cylinder supply lasts approximately 3 to 4 months. Depleted cylinders are normally replaced when the second cylinder reaches 50% capacity or less. The fiberglass enclosure housing the cylinders is secured behind a pad locked chain link fence enclosure, and access is restricted to trained and authorized personnel.
    In the event of a detected leak, the 24 hour Command Center is notified electronically and emergency response procedures are initiated. Should a leak be detected by other methods (visual, odor, etc.), employees are trained to call the Command Center at extension 4444.
b) Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
    The gaseous chlorine disinfection system consists of two (2) 150 lb. chlorine cylinders mounted vertically in an outdoor fiberglass enclosure adjacent to the B4 well house, and approximately 45 feet of ??A? inch polyethylene tubing supplying chlorine gas to an air stripper.
c) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
    Raytheon reviews all materials and processes prior to implementation and prior to any significant change. Current release prevention methods and controls are implemented where required and available. The chlorine cylinders are equipped with manual shutoff valves and Cap

ital Control Advance Series 200 vacuum gas feeders, firmly mounted in a vertical upright position, stored outdoors in a locked area, and equipped with a gas detection and alarm system.
d) Five Year Accident History
    There have been no accidents in the last five years.
e) Emergency Response Program
    Raytheon maintains an emergency response capability at the site including trained personnel and equipment. The Emergency Response Program is outlined in the Emergency Preparedness Plan ??A? 2009 (Introduction included below) and in the Emergency Response Plan (or Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan) as submitted annually under the Hazardous Materials Unified Program to the Santa Barbara County Fire Department.

1.    INTRODUCTION
1.1    Purpose and Scope
The purpose of this plan is to establish a continuing program of preparation for and appropriate response to all types of emergencies affecting Raytheon SB County sites and personnel. This plan specifies procedures for managing various types of emergency incidents including response to fires, explosions, medical emergencies, bomb threats, civil disturbances, workplace violence, hazardous materials releases, severe weather, flooding and earthquakes.
1.2    Annual Updates
This plan will be updated annually or as needed.
1.3    Type of Facilities
Raytheon has four campuses located on or adjacent to Hollister Avenue within a two-mile radius of each other and in Lompoc.  They are EW main campus, RVS main campus, EW west campus and RVS Lompoc campus.
1.4    Distribution of Plan
This plan will be restricted to principal Site Incident Support Team staff members reporting to the EW and RVS General Managers and also Emergency Services - Management team members.

Copies of this plan will be marked and handled as Raytheon Proprietary.  Copies may be made available to:

Santa Barbara County Fire Department
Santa Barbara County Fire / CUPA
Lompoc City Fire Department 
Santa Barbara County Sheriff??A?s Department

1.5    Plan Implementation
Implementation o

f this plan is effective immediately upon request of on-scene Incident Commanders and / or Emergency Operations Center Command staff.

This plan is designed to meet Raytheon Enterprise Preparedness - Emergency Planning requirements in addition to applicable local, state and federal emergency preparedness requirements including:

29 CFR 1910.120    Emergency Response Operations
29 CFR 1910.165    Site Evacuation Plan
29 CFR 1910.138     Site Fire Prevention and Emergency Plan

1.6    DISCLOSURE LIMITATIONS
Due to the sensitive nature of the enclosed material, please take every precaution to secure it when not in use.

TO BE TREATED AS RAYTHEON PROPRIETARY

Holders of the Emergency Preparedness Plan showing unlisted telephone numbers will be restricted to Sr. Management, Emergency Management, and the 24-hour Security Control Center.  Security Control Center personnel will not release any phone number (listed or unlisted), but will relay the message to the manager concerned who will be requested to return the call.

Do not further distribute this manual without the approval of the site Emergency Services Manager.

1-Portable Monitoring: Purchase of portable PID with Cl sensor         complete by Sep-10
2-Training: Purchase of Chlorine Institute training DVD on Kit A     complete by Sep-10
3-Fixed Monitoring: MSA condition, operating parameters, and hardware being reviewed by ISS and Facilities.                                                 complete by Oct-10
4-Signage: Chlorine Alarm Protocol sign being developed by EHS and Facilities, printed by Media Solutions                                                 complete by Oct-10
5-Cylinder Acceptance: Review Praxair inspection procedures, develop Raytheon procedure for cylinder inspection and acceptance.                                 complete by Nov-10
6-Wind Conditions: Windsock being purchased by EHS                 complete by Nov-10
7-Labeling: New labels to be installed on equipment and piping

complete by Nov-10
8-Fixed Monitoring: Alarm light being upgraded to more visible unit, second visible alarm being added                                                 complete by Nov-10
9-Lighting: Interior and exterior lights being repaired                 complete by Oct-10
10-Training: Integration of chlorine safety training into emergency response training program                                                                 complete by Oct-10
11-Portable Monitoring: Review IH lab inventory, purchase Draeger tubes for Cl (if required)                                                         complete by Oct-10
12-Security: Contact Bevco Engineering for cabinet lock and key(s)   complete by Oct-10
